title: scotlands-insider-guide-balloch
story: The Vale of Leven settlement at the foot of the loch acts as the gateway to Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park, but with an array of family-friendly attractions, good shopping and restaurants, and a lovely marina, it is increasingly a year-round draw.Historical highlightsPeople first settled around Loch Lomond around  years ago in the Neolithic era and there is evidence that Viking raiders ransacked the islands.The lands around Balloch ndash which means ldquovillage on the loch in Gaelic - were granted to the Lennox family in  by King Malcolm III, and the original Balloch Castle was built there in the th century.Loch Lomond became an established destination for visitors in the th century and was already popular enough for James Boswell to remark on hisfrom the Western Isles with Dr Johnson in  that he did not need to describe it in his journal.Balloch, which sits on the River Leven, grew up around the second Balloch Castle, the early th century country house built by aristocrat John Buchanan, bought by Glasgow City Corporation in  and leased by West Dunbartonshire Council since . The estate was designated a country park in  and has been part of the National Park since .The townrsquos population of , rose by , when Oasis played in the park in .The Loch Lomond Shores leisure development opened in  providing jobs for local people and a focal point for visitors.Things to doWhether you arrive in Balloch by car, train or boat, a walk around the marina is a must to get a feel for lochside le and admire the vast array of pleasure boats moored all year round.A saunter along the boardwalk will put you in the mood for a boat trip, and youre spoiled for choice round these parts. In spring and summer, the lovingly restored art deco paddle steamer Maid of the Lochmakes for a beautul sight on the water. Sweeney Cruises , meanwhile, sails all year round on a fleet of dferent-sized vessels, with daily hour-long trips taking in some of the lochrsquos  islands and recorded commentaries from Scots TV historian Neil Oliver.Back on dry land but continuing the watery theme, the Sea Le Aquarium at Loch Lomond Shoresis home to sharks, rays and seahorses. Predominantly aimed at children, the exhibits are fun and informative.Beautul Orla the golden eagle is the main attraction at the nearby Bird of Prey centre .Balloch Country Park has  acres of woodland, meadow, formal gardens, playparks and shoreline to discover. Follow the Fairy Trail of tree stumps, enjoy a picnic and,the wind is up, fly a kite. A circular walk takes around an hour and the paths are in good condition which makes it accessible for all. In July, the Loch Lomond highland games - which grew out of the Balloch Show - draws spectators from far and wide.If its a family-friendly forest adventure youre after, the zip wires, balance beams, tight-ropes and scramble nets of TreeZoneare definitely worth a go. Open at weekends during winter.Where to eatCucina in Balloch Galleries is a firm favourite with visitors and locals, serving up Italian classics such as pizza and pasta in a comfortable, informal setting. Therersquos a full selection of sandwiches and paninis at lunchtime and an attractive set-menu deal in the evening. You can also do take-out.The Stables Restaurant on Carrochan Road gets rave reviews for the friendly service as well as the food. The piping hot pies are particularly tempting on a chilly autumn day, while the sticky toffee pudding is a must at any time of year.The Balcony Bar and Grill at Loch Lomond Shoresserves food all day, offering a delicious full Scottish breakfast as well lunch and dinner. The balcony has stunning views to Ben Lomond, perhaps best enjoyed with a glass of wine on a balmy summerrsquos evening.As the name suggests, the Waterside Inn sits just a stonersquos throw from the bonny banks and serves a full menu, including daily specials, washed down with a fine selection of ales, wines and spirits.If itrsquos a hearty bowl of soup and a fluffy scone yoursquore looking for, meanwhile, you canrsquot beat the award-winning cafe at the Loch Lomond Homes and Garden Centre on Stirling Road.Where to shopLoch Lomond shores has an eclectic mix of independent and high street stores. Misty Glen is great for gts, homeware and jewellery, while Pavers Shoes focuses on comfort and quality, and offers a great selection of walking shoes and boots.Hawkshead stocks outdoor clothing and accessories, while the Grape Seed specialises in nuts, seeds and dried food - exactly the sort of stuff that keeps you going on a hike.Therersquos also a Jennersat the development, which has authentic Italian deli Valvona and Crolla in the foodhall and Cafeacute Zest, the ideal place to enjoy a glass of bubbly while you shop.Loch Lomond Brewery, in Lomond Industrial Estate, showcases the award-winning local craft beer.Where to stayComfortable: Just five minutes from the country park, the Balloch House Hotelhas been providing hospitality for more than  years and mixes rustic charm with modern convenience. Rooms - many of which have lovely views over the river ndash start at pound a night.Family friendly: Lomond Woods Holiday Park has a wide range of lodges , glamping pods and caravans to suit every group and budget. From pound a night.Right on the water: Airbnbhas a fully-equipped two-bedroom apartment overlooking the marina. Sleeps five, from pound a night.Famous facesTexas singer Sharleen Spiteri grew up in the town, as did Olympic and Commonwealth swimmer Ross Murdoch.Much-admired writer Agnes Owens, who influenced the likes of James Kelman and Alasdair Gray, lived in Balloch for many years.What to do nearbyPretty Luss, which many still know as fictional Glendarroch from cult s soap Take The High Road, is just nine miles north of Balloch. Itrsquos usually pretty packed in summer, but a crisp autumn or winter day can make for the perfect visit, featuring a walk along the shore, followed by a cappuccino and muffin in the Coach House Coffee Shop.Itrsquos well worth the short boat trip to Inchmurrin, the biggest fresh water island in the UK, which even has its own th century castle. Both Robert the Bruce and Mary Queen of Scots are known to have visited the island, which has beautul walks, beaches and the ruins of a th century monastery. You can even stay from Easter to October.The stunning Falls of Falloch just outside Crianlarich are a  minute drive north. A spectacular backdrop for a picnic.At m Conic Hill, which rises above nearby Balmaha, is the ideal ldquowee hill for beginners and children. The views from the top, across Loch Lomond to Glasgow and beyond are awe-inspiring. The walk down is always sweetened by the thought of a well-earned lunch the Oak Tree Inn in Balmaha.

title: why-ballet-dance-classes-are-the-latest-fitness-and-stress-busting-trend
story: Why ballet dance classes are the latest fitness and stress-busting trendMaggie Ritchie, foreground left with dance teacher Olivia McLaypictured duringltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt a + ballet class ltspan classtruncate-full-screengtat the Dance Factory, Calder street, Govanhill. Photograph by Colin MearnsWhy ballet dance classes are the latest fitness and stress-busting trendMaggie Ritchie left with dance teacher Olivia McLayPhotograph by Colin Mearltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtnsWhy ballet dance classes are the latest fitness and stress-busting trendDance teacher Olivia McLay pictured during a + ballet class at the Dance Factoltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtry, Calder street, Gltspan classtruncate-full-screengtovanhill.Photograph by Colin MearnsWhy ballet dance classes are the latest fitness and stress-busting trend Maggie Ritchie, centre, pictured taking part in a + ballet class at the Danceltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt Factory, Calder strltspan classtruncate-full-screengteet, Govanhill.Photograph by Colin MearnsWhy ballet dance classes are the latest fitness and stress-busting trendDance teacher Olivia McLay pictured during a + ballet class at the Dance Factoltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtry, Calder street, Gltspan classtruncate-full-screengtovanhill.Photograph by Colin Mearns April THWARTED as a child by being told I was too tall to be a ballet dancer, Irsquove always loved it and have been hooked ever since on dance films such as Dirty Dancing, Strictly Ballroom, and, of course, Fame.Who could fail to be thrilled by formidable dance teacher Lydia Grant, who told her students in the s TV adaptation of Fame: ldquoYoursquove got big dreams  You want fame  Well, fame costs. And right here is where you start paying hellip in sweat.Imagine, then, my excitement when I found out that itrsquos not too late to don a leotard and pair of footless tights ndash legwarmers optional ndash and release my inner ballerina.Adult ballet is a fast growing trend, thanks mostly to the revived interest in dance sparked by the reality TV series Strictly Come Dancing.There are now adult classical ballet classes for Absolute Beginners at Scottish Ballet, where you can learn how to do a plieacute without the pressure of feeling like a failureyou donrsquot make the corps de ballet.Anybody of any age, shape or fitness level can and does take part in these classes. Ballet is great for fitness, boosting cardio, strength and flexibility, co-ordination and balance and is weight-bearing so it helps build muscles and bones. Ballet burns  calories an hour ndash more than a spin class ndash and is fantastic for posture and is also a known stress buster.There are waiting lists to get on the Scottish Ballet -week courses for absolute beginner, beginner and intermediate dancers and I found out why when I signed up for an absolute beginnersrsquo class there.Dance teacher Preston Clare is not quite as strict as Debbie Allenrsquos character Lydia Grant in Fame, but he does insist on correct technique with his students, who range in age from  to late s.ldquoI want everyone to be safe, so I teach them how to bend with their knees over the toes and the proper way to move through the foot against the floor so there arenrsquot any injuries, he says.One of the joys of teaching this class, Preston says, is watching the transformation in his students.ldquoTherersquos one man who is quite heavy. He had such a curved spine and hunched shoulders that when he lay flat on his back, his head couldnrsquot touch the floor. After a few weeks of ballet, he can now lie flat and hersquos lost a lot of weight.One of the reasons ballet is such an effective way to change your body, he explains, is the music ndash classes at Scottish ballet are accompanied by pianist Michael Barnett.ldquoProfessional ballet dancers have the physiques of athletes but dance is an art form, not a sport. The music lts you up ndash it helps you reach that bit further.Preston shows me into the large, bright studio at Scottish Balletrsquos headquarters at the Tramway in Glasgow. I gaze longingly at a pile of colourful tutus stacked outside the class but have to content myself with what Irsquom wearing: gym gear I usually wear to pilates. I notice the other women are in black leotards and tights with flippy little ballet skirts, but at least I have proper soft ballet shoes.Irsquove always been hopeless at learning new steps and Irsquom a little nervous about looking like one of the dancing hippos in Disneyrsquos Fantasia. However, Preston reassures me that everyone starts out the same.ldquoRelax and have fun, he says. ldquoMy students know they are not going to join a ballet company they are here to enjoy themselves. I love teaching adult beginners because they are so dedicated.Alexandra Lesley, an actress in her early s, and her partner, Keith Hooley, , are certainly committed: they travel from Thornhill in Dumfriesshire to attend the class once a week, a round trip of three hours.ldquoI love it. I get such a buzz and come out walking on air, says Alexandra. ldquoBallet keeps me fit and flexible.Keith, a retired quality controller, says: ldquoAlexandra encouraged me to go with her and I really enjoy it. My sciatica cleared up after one class and I donrsquot slouch any more. It also helps to keep my mind sharp ndash ballet doesnrsquot just exercise your muscles, joints and ligaments. At home we practise in the kitchen, using the counter tops as a barre.Josh Polson, , a teacher from Glasgow, has been impressed by how much more flexible and stronger he is playing American football since starting ballet last year. He was inspired to take up ballet after seeing his girlfriend, who is with Scottish Ballet, on stage.ldquoIrsquod never done anything like this before and wanted to see how dficult it was. Now I have even more respect for my girlfriend and how hard she works.Josh, too, finds the benefits arenrsquot just physical.ldquoI have a stressful job teaching children with behavioural dficulties. Ballet is very calming and allows me to switch off because Irsquom focusing so much on the steps.Itrsquos time for me to join the class. We start off with some simple barre exercises and I soon get into the swing of things, despite wobbling when we have to let go the barre and balance on tiptoe on one leg. Preston keeps the atmosphere light with some teasing and jokes and Irsquom soon having fun.ldquoThis is easy-peasy, I think, dreaming of skipping straight to beginners. But it soon gets harder as we move into a Polonaise ndash a skipping, sliding dance invented by Louis IV, to allow men at his court to show off their calves. I soon get mixed up with the steps but manage to keep up. The pirouette is trickier to master as you have to whip your head around as you turn to avoid being dizzy. I end up dizzy ndash and hot and sweaty.Ballet is much harder than I expected and the next day my calf, arm and stomach muscles ache.A beginnersrsquo over-s class, surely, will be easier. But the class at Dance Factory on Glasgowrsquos Southside, is also demanding. After a few simple barre exercises, I end up tripping over two left feet during the dance sequence. I can sort of do the graceful arms, though, and channel Margot Fonteyn. The other women skip about with confidence, landing softly when they jump, their backs straight and arms properly swan-like. They may be in their s and s, but there isnrsquot a middle-aged spread or dowagerrsquos hump to be seen.ldquoBallet is excellent for strengthening your core and improving posture, says dance teacher Olivia McLay. ldquoItrsquos good for menopausal women because it builds bone mass ndash bones begin to thin at that age. It improves physical and mental agility, helps with balance, co-ordination and memory because you have to learn a sequence of steps.ldquoI sleep better, Irsquom stronger and feel more stretched and mindful, says Linda Weir, , from Glasgow. lsquoI just love it and would recommend it as a way to be stronger and fitter. Irsquove also made friends.Alison Lock, , from Glasgow said: ldquoItrsquos a physical and mental workout. Itrsquos much more fun than going to the gym, and it has stopped me feeling isolated.Linda Trainor, , was a talented ballerina as a child who won a scholarship at to the Royal Academy of Dance, but had to leave when her mother died.ldquoI always felt there was a hole in my le and itrsquos been wonderful to go back to ballet, even this late in le. It makes me happy.The many physical and mental benefits are the reason Scottish Ballet has classes for people with dementia, Parkinsonrsquos Disease, and a class for the elderly called Regenerate. Soon there will a class for people with multiple sclerosis.ldquoThere are proven benefits, says Catherine Cassidy, director of engagement at Scottish Ballet, who has seen a growing interest in the adult beginnersrsquo classes since they started three years ago.ldquoBallet improves balance, co-ordination and fluidity of movement. The music and rhythm combined with visualising unfolding your wings like a swan, for example, helps people with neurological conditions to move.ldquoBallet is also relaxing and gives you a sense of achievement as you master new skills. The mental health benefits are huge.Kerry Livingstone, head of the associatesrsquo programme at Scottish Ballet and head of Ballet at the Royal Conservatoire, says: ldquoIn these fast-paced days of social media and constant interruptions from emails and text messages, ballet forces you to concentrate fully and is great for mindfulness. It gives you self-discipline and because itrsquos an art, itrsquos uplting and creative.Undeterred by my clumsiness and encouraged by Preston and Olivia, Irsquove signed up for an Absolute Beginners course at Scottish Ballet ndash and Irsquom absolutely loving it.Ill never be the next Darcy Bussell but Irsquoll hopefully be stronger, more flexible and have the poise and graceful posture of a ballerina.See www.scottishballet and www.dancefactory

title: herald-calendar-captures-the-beauty-of-scotland
story: Herald calendar captures the beauty of ScotlandAn early morning view of the River Shiel near to Acharacle, on the Ardnamurchan ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtpeninsula. Taken witltspan classtruncate-full-screength my Canon D MK and Sigma mm lens.   second at F.Herald calendar captures the beauty of ScotlandThe sunset glow silhouetting the Isle of Arran and the shipwreck of the MV Kaffiltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtr.This Clyde Pufferltspan classtruncate-full-screengt was ran aground off the entrance to Ayr harbour in September .Itrsquos an attitude that has stood him in very good stead. Though he only took up photography eight years ago he has shown his talents in repeated entries in The Heralds Picture of the Day slot and in our annual charity calendar. This yearrsquos calendar, which is now on sale, features two excellent shots of his ndash Buachaille Etive Mograver on the cover, and the railway bridge at Loch Awe as the illustration for August.Mr Stokes, , who lives in Dunoon, has been retired for  years. For  years ndash  with his own business ndash he designed and carved gravestones.ldquoWe covered the islands and up north, we had agents all over the place, he said this week. ldquoI took up photography in , because my we was getting fed up looking at me, and it has given me more of an artistic look at le than when I had all the design work I was doing with the gravestones for all these years.He was taken under the wing of Archie Reid, a Dunoon photographer, and a friend of his when they were younger.ldquoEverything is kept simple and basic. Compose your image, donrsquot just go running at it. Walk around. I try to do that so that when I get to the screen, therersquos very little left to do.ldquoMy camera is a Canon D that I bought from Archie. Itrsquos not like the huge cameras you can get nowadays. I use a couple of filters [attached to the front of the lens to enhance the final shot] and my favourite lens is a Sigma mm-mm. Archie put me onto it, and I can do everything with it. I also have a mm-m Canon, which is a great lens but I havenrsquot used it as often as I thought I would.ldquoI always use a tripod and a remote control when Irsquom doing serious pictures ndash I prefer not to hand-hold the camera in that sort of situation, involving long exposures. If yoursquore shooting a waterfall you might need an exposure of three or four seconds, for example.At first, Mr Stokes did wildle photography, ldquobut there is so much time involved in it, he says. ldquoItrsquos heartbreaking, trying to get a bird to land in a specic place or a squirrel to do your bidding. But landscape photography has its own heartache as well. You can run down to a scene where there are perfect reflections in the water but by the time you get down to the loch, it is full of ripples hellip and it drives it nuts, but that is all part of the fun.His shot of Buachaille Etive Mograver was taken from the frozen river at Kingshouse Hotel, in Glencoe. And at Loch Awe his eye was caught by the ldquototal flat calm of the reflection.ldquoThe two shots were bonus pictures, as I call them. Irsquom usually up at four in the morning when I leave Dunoon and Irsquom up north in pitch darkness, waiting for sunrise. Then I work my way through til about pm and I think, thatrsquoll do me.ldquoI shot both Buachaille and Loch Awe on my way home, though I donrsquot think they were on the same day. But it was nice to look at them once I got home.His work in The Heraldrsquos daily picture slot certainly has its fans. One woman has a file of all of his images that have been printed since , and she uses them as picture cards to send to family and friends. Other people have asked him for copies of his images. He is only too happy to oblige.ldquoI donrsquot make any charge, he adds. ldquoIrsquom just happy, getting back into le, and being nice to people. A lot of people, after all, canrsquot get out and about.TO ORDER YOUR CALENDARGo to https:heraldandtimes.myshopy collections the-herald or call   to order your calendar and pay by debit credit card. The Herald calendar costs pound., inc UK PP, with all profits going to Kilbryde Hospice in East Kilbride. Please allow up to  days for delivery.

title: scots-share-stories-of-their-favourite-trees
story: THE Suffragette Oak that stands on Kelvin Way in Glasgow ndash right across the road from Hillhead Primary ndash was planted in  to commemorate women getting the vote. I noticed it one day when I went to collect my son. This would have been around .I mentioned it to a friend. She and I were in the same womens group and a friend of hers had died from breast cancer. The brass plaque beside the tree was mottled and not very well looked after.One day I saw my friend cleaning it. She told me that her friend who died had been active in the feminist economic movement and she was cleaning the plaque in her memory. The Glasgow Womens Library got involved and they campaigned for it to be Tree of the Year in .The Suffragette Oak makes me think about the forgotten history of these women: the hard work and striving that went unnoticed. Thanks to these women who went that extra mile, we now have the vote ndash we have a voice.The tree was badly damaged in a storm last year and the council had to make it safe. The bits cut off were given to Glasgow Womens Library and they are making it into things to sell to raise funds. Isnt that lovely Another special tree was one I saw at a holiday place we rented at Achnacloich, near Oban.The gardens there have this amazing redwood that looks like a gigantic hand.The reason it looks like a hand was that when it was planted a rabbit kept nibbling the bud in the middle. Every time this rabbit nibbled it, another shoot would come out the side. It was one of the first redwoods to be grown in Scotland.We were staying there with loads of kids and it was the best climbing tree in the world ndash they would get lost in it.You would be sitting outside having a cup of tea in the morning and suddenly hear a wee voice from up in the tree asking: "Whats your favourite flavour of crisps "Carole Baxter, Beechgrove Garden presenterI LOVE rowan trees. All the species are beautul. There is such a range of colourful berries and they are a hardy plant. In my garden in Aberdeenshire I have eight ieties including cashmiriana, Joseph Rock and the native rowan.I have enjoyed the rowan for its berries as long as I can remember, certainly from a young age. It is a value-for-money plant: you have the blossom and fruits, lovely foliage and great autumn colour.People perhaps arent aware of the range of species and named ieties. You dont need to have the one that has the orange-red berries you can get white, yellow and pink berries.There are some small ones as well, such as Sorbus reducta which is ideal for a rock garden. We have that one at Beechgrove as well as vilmorinii, which has pink berries with almost blueish foliage. Those were my plant choices.What is interesting is that birds tend to home in on the red and orange berries to start off with so,you have cashmiriana with its white berries, it tends to hold the berries a bit longer.This year has been particularly good for the fruits because we had a cold spring and it gradually got warmer, so we didnt have the frost and the blossoms werent damaged, which was then followed by a nice hot summer.It is nothing to do with the fact we are going to have a hard winter as people often say ndash thats an old wives tale ndash it is the fact that we have had a good season.Episodes of Beechgrove Garden are available on BBC iPlayer until November Gordon Buchanan, wildle filmmakerSCOTS pine has been my favourite tree from a young age. I grew up on Mull and I have always loved woodland. I spent a lot of time as a kid walking through the woods.One walk we did took us a mile or so out of Tobermory. When you are eight or nine, even just going a couple of miles out of town feels like you are exploring the other side of the planet.It was while out walking that I first saw a Scots pine. It was one of those classic old "granny" pines with so much character, the limbs were all twisted ndash there was one that came out at a right angle and shot skywards.This Scots pine stood among mixed birch and there was no other tree around it that looked the same. It seemed so exotic and out of place. Your eye was drawn to it.As I got older and spent time in the Cairngorms and Abernethy Forest, I learned that much of Scotland was covered in forests filled with these trees. I thought it was the most magical habitat.The tree then became a symbol for all the wildle that you find living in those forests. I have spent time filming capercaillie as well as red deer, red squirrels and pine martens among the trees.Weirdly, now I have travelled further than just a couple of miles out of town, whenever I see Scots pine, they dont look exotic to me. I have recently been working in Russia where there is mixed birch woodland and what I call "Caledonian Forest" ndash this reminder of home.My love of Scots pine is undiminished but they have gone from being a symbol of the exotic to something very familiar.A couple of years ago I was working in a mountainous region of Turkey and you could almost have been in the Cairngorms. It was very similar. I felt at home.Animal Families and Me with Gordon Buchanan is at Kirkintilloch Town Hall on November , Brunton Theatre in Musselburgh on November  and Rothes Halls in Glenrothes on November Kirsty Wark, broadcasterA TREE is a marker, something you look out for at a particular time of year. My Japanese maple in the garden, for example, you just know when the leaves are going to turn, be vivid and then flutter to the ground.The yellow-berried rowan is one of my favourite trees. I love lime trees because I think they are so vivid in the landscape.Trees represent a constancy. Planting trees is entirely altruistic because, unless they are fast-growing, you are never in your letime going to get the real benefit of them. I love the fact that parks were laid out by the Victorians ndash and even much earlier with Lancelot "Capability" Brown.After my father died, we planted a rowan where he loved to fish most, which was Kendoon Loch in Galloway. That was in . It is beside the water and Im not sure it is the most fertile place for it, but it is hanging on in there. I went to see it last week.In Celtic mythology the rowan symbolises courage and protection. That is why you will often see old houses with rowans planted in the front garden by the gate. We planted a red rowan for Dad, but I really like a yellow rowan too.I used to know the names of all the trees because I was in the Brownies. I dont know them all now. I love walking in the forest up to Glenashdale Falls and Whiting Bay on Arran, those specic spaces where you are surrounded by flora and fauna.Sir John Lister-Kaye, author and naturalistTHERE is an ash tree that is one of the biggest trees in the garden here at House of Aigas near Beauly and almost certainly the oldest ndash it is possibly  years old. It is right beside the house.Ashwas a very valuable timber throughout the th and th centuries. It was used for all sorts of things ndash implement handles, cart frames, furniture.It is a very good, close-grained hardwood. Very few ash trees ever survived more than  or  years, perhaps  years, because they were too valuable. Highlanders were not well off and it was a good way of making money.There are very few old ash trees in the Highlands. This one has survived simply because it is so close to an th-century house and I think the owners must have said many times: "Dont fell that tree, we like it". And so it survived.What is wonderful about it is that it has survived for so long and that means it has seen so much. For instance, it will have seen Bonnie Prince Charlie come through raising the clans which, of course, culminated in the Battle of Culloden.It saw the folk mourning after the loss of Culloden and it saw Cholmondeleys regiment come and camp here and then burn the tacksmans house down right beside it. The tree must have been scorched by that fire. The Frasers who were living here at the time were all murdered in May .It has witnessed some real horrors. Later, it will have witnessed the Highland Clearances, people pulling out and leaving for the New World. It will have witnessed the Victorians arriving with their grand ideas and turning the place into a sporting estate.This "loftier ash", as I call it ndash because that is what Fraxinus excelsior means ndash has seen a lot of history and for that reason alone it is a very valuable tree. In my book Song of the Rolling Earth: A Highland Odyssey, I dedicated a whole chapter to it.Let me read you a bit from it: "The ash tree has witnessed it all. I stand at its foot. Great roots have corrugated the ground around it with broad woody thongs undulating outwards in a circular plate of tangle and deep grip, roots that trail far across the lawns in every direction."It is solid, purposeful, locked in. Its trunk writhes with power. It is all heart. My fullest reach, both arms stretched, extends to less than a third of its circumference an inconsequential hug leaving me in awe of its rigid grandeur."Its bark is deeply grooved with long vertical ripples of hardness like a throng of ribbed buttresses all heading upward, shoring up its might, shedding veils of green dust at my touch."The bark fissures draw in treecreepers: those tiny mouse-like birds that dash upwards in little jerky pulses, defying gravity. Then, giving in to the earths pull, they flick down again, back to start, like a game of snakes and ladders never won."I am enthralled by this tree, rapt. Every time I stand here, I shrink it grows. I age it shrugs off such foibles and just goes on expanding into a thousand shaded alleys. What is  minutes or a week when you are  years old "Song of the Rolling Earth: A Highland Odyssey by Sir John Lister-Kaye is published by Abacus, priced pound.. Visit aigasPaul Murton, Grand Tours of Scotland presenterA TREE that I have always admired is a rowan that grows from a huge boulder. It is one that everyone will have seen as they are driving north up the A to Fort William.Just as you get to Rannoch Moor and are climbing up above Loch Tulla, there on the left-hand side of the road is a massive boulder left over from the Ice Age.There is a crack in it where, for many years, this amazing little rowan tree has been growing.It has been blasted by the elements and cant be getting many nutrients from the rock, so I dont know how it survives.There is something quite symbolic about it. I have filmed it several times for programmes over the years. It also appears in one of my favourite books, Mountaineering in Scotland by WH Murray.In fact, the first time I saw this rowan tree was in WH Murrays book when I was  or .I hitchhiked from Dunoon to Glencoe to go climbing and I remember seeing it in the flesh and thinking: "Oh, thats the one in the book".That was exciting because I felt I was on the trail of real mountaineers. Any mountaineer who had been up to Glencoe going back decades will have seen that wee tree.How did it end up there  Perhaps a crow or a raven carried a berry, dropped it and it then got stuck in a crack where there was enough nutrients for roots to grow. It must be at least  years old.Im a bit of a secret tree hugger. I planted a lot of trees at my mothers place in Argyll years ago and it is nice to admire how much they have grown. There are a couple of chestnut trees, beech trees and Scots pine.Episodes of Grand Tours of Scotlands Lochs are available on BBC iPlayer until November . The series will be repeated on BBC in Greg McHugh, actorI GREW up in Morningside in Edinburgh and at the bottom of the garden were steps down to a wood. There was a mud road with a wall and trees behind it. I loved spending time there.All the kids in my street would go down and play. It was an incredible place. I know people think of Morningside as being posh, but this wasnt a kept space. It was completely wild and overgrown. My mum would always shout as I went out the door: "Dont go near the giant hogweed!"It was this little hidden spot in the city. When I was in third year at school, I did a history project on it and learned that this was the old "poorhouse" road that had grown over.To think of the families that would have walked up and down there, the trees have been witness to all of that.We would gather conkers, climb and make rope swings among the trees and put old doors down over the stream. On fireworks night there would be a big bonfire and all the families in the street went along.One of my brothers mates stood on a wasps nest and was incredibly badly stung. Afterwards it gave spending time among the trees a new element of risk. The thing that sticks in my mind is that, while during the day it was our playground, we would never dare go down there at night.The inaugural Scottish Tree Festival organised by Discover Scottish Gardens features more than  tree-themed events and runs until December . title: scotlands-25-best-loved-trees
story: THE Fortingall Yew, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe.There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old, although others believe it could be a remnant of a post-Roman Christian site dating back , years. A figure of , to , years has also been suggested.According to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child.One story suggests that Pilatersquos father was on a diplomatic mission to a Pictish king when news of his sonrsquos birth reached Fortingall, another that his pregnant we had been travelling with him and a third that the child was born after an illicit liaison with a local woman.More recently the legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in . A patron to writers such as Rudyard Kipling and Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Sir Donald is said to have invented the tale as a prank with help from his literary friends.The Dool Tree, Blairquhan Castle, AyrshireDool or dule trees were used as natural gallows for public hangings ndash and often displayed the corpse for some weeks afterwards. They were common on many estates until the mid-th century. The ancient sycamore that stands in the shadow of Blairquhan Castle is believed to be a dool tree planted in the th century during the reign of King James V of Scotland.Hawthorn Tree at Cawdor Castle and Gardens near NairnIt is said that around , William, rd Thane of Cawdor, set out to build a replacement castle on a less marshy site than its predecessor. To find a location, he followed instructions said to have come to him in a dream and loaded panniers of gold on the back of a donkey.William followed the animal as it roamed across his lands. When night fell, it rested under a tree on a higher and rockier site close to the steep-sided Allt Dearg.The castle was built on that spot with the unique quirk that it was constructed around the tree. This subsequently became a feature of part of the cellar, known since as ldquoThe Hawthorn Room.Legend has it that the tree has magical qualities which have on more than one occasion saved the castle from disaster.Modern scientic analysis has revealed that the tree died in approximately , most likely as a result of being deprived of light because the castle had been built around it. The other surprise  It is a holly tree, not a hawthorn. It still stands in the cellar to this day.Champion trees, ious locationsScotland boasts many champion trees: the largest, tallest and the exceptional. There is a Champion Tree Trail at Mount Stuart on Bute which features a Corsican pine, an evergreen coner planted around  which has grown to ft .Ardkinglas Woodland Garden at Cairndow, Argyll has an impressive collection of champion trees, including ldquothe mightiest coner in Europe, a European silver fir with an almost ftgirth.Dawyck Botanic Garden near Peebles is home to some of Britainrsquos oldest and tallest trees including a European silver fir planted in  during the reign of King Charles II. There are Douglas firs that date back to , grown from the original seed sent home by the famous botanist David Douglas.The Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh has a striking paperbark maple which is easy to identy, even in winter thanks to its eye-catching form of self-exfoliation. As the old sheaves of the copper-red bark die, they peel themselves off revealing the young, smooth bark beneath.The changeable colours of the treersquos leaves are equally dazzling. Starting out as orange in the spring, they become a pinkish-brown and then yellow, before finally turning deep green.By late autumn, the leaves have taken on a deep red hue, complementing its peeling, coppery bark. The paperbark maple was first collected in China at the turn of the th century by botanist Ernest Henry Wilson.Bicycle Tree near Brig orsquo Turk, TrossachsDating from the late th century, the so-called ldquoBicycle Tree is a sycamore reputed to have self-seeded beside the scrap heap of the village blacksmith in Brig orsquo Turk. As it grew, it absorbed ndash or swallowed up ndash several metal objects, including a bicycle and, reputedly, a shiprsquos anchor and chain.There is a fable about a young man conscripted to the First World War who left his bicycle hanging over a branch. Some say he never came back ndash orhe didfound that the tree had claimed the two-wheeled steed as its own. Today all that remains are the handlebars sticking out of the trunk.William Wallace Yew, Elderslie, RenfrewshireTwo symbolic trees once stood side-by-side: the Wallace Oak and the Wallace Yew. Now only the latter remains. Some doubt has been cast on the age, yet parish records from the s refer to it as ldquothis ancient tree. It stands near to where William Wallace is reputed to have been born in .Robertrsquos Brucersquos Yew, Loch LomondWilliam Wallace isnrsquot the only Scottish hero to have his own yew. Perched on a rocky outcrop on Loch Lomond, this ancient tree is where Robert the Bruce is said to have sheltered from his enemies in  while recounting tales of valour to keep his troopsrsquo spirits up.Wollemi pines, Inverewe Garden and Estate, Poolewe, Ross-shireInverewe boasts the worldrsquos most northerly grove of a Jurassic tree. Wollemi pine was thought to have died out two million years ago, but the species was discovered in Australia in the early s. Eight were planted at Inverewe in .Nettyrsquos Tree, Eriskay, Outer HebridesNewly crowned as Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year  in a Woodland Trust poll, this spruce known as ldquoNettyrsquos Tree was, until recently, the only tree on Eriskay. It was planted more than  years ago by the poet, priest and land rights activist Father Allan McDonald.Netty MacDonald lived on the nearby croft and encouraged the islandrsquos children to play on the tree as their cries and laughter reminded her of her own family who had grown up and moved away to work. Netty died aged  in . Her daughter now lives on the croft and continues the tradition.Rizziorsquos Chestnut, Melville Castle Hotel, near DalkeithAccording to folklore, this Spanish chestnut tree was planted for Mary Queen of Scots by her Italian private secretary David Rizzio as a token of his love for her. The Queen responded by planting five oak trees along the drives which also survive to this day.A less public declaration may have been prudent. After rumours spread that the pair were lovers, a group of outraged Scottish nobles stabbed Rizzio  times. His brutal murder took place in front of the seven-months-pregnant queen at Holyrood Palace in .The Caledonian ForestMuch of the Highlands and what is now the Cairngorms National Park was once covered with the Caledonian Forest estimated in its heyday, around , BC, to have spanned . million hectares, about a fth of Scotlandrsquos land mass.By , BC, however, as the climate became wetter and windier, the forest was reduced signicantly. It continued to shrink in size from then onwards largely due to human intervention.Today the Caledonian Forest exists in  remnants. The Scots pine trees found here are directly descended from the native pinewoods that grew around , BC and once formed the westernmost outpost of the Boreal Forest in Europe.Beneath the vast forest canopy, the likes of wild boar, lynx, brown bears and grey wolves ndash now extinct in the wild in Scotland ndash roamed.The Caledonian Forest is still home to some of the rarest wildle in the British Isles, including mountain hare, pine marten, red squirrel, Scottish wildcats, capercaillie, crested tit and Scottish crossbill.It was revealed last month that a poundm Endangered Landscapes Programme has selected the Caledonian Forest to be the focus of a key restoration project ndash along with seven other major regeneration schemes ndash to restore Europersquos most threatened environments.Mallochrsquos Oak, Strathallan Castle, PerthshireThere is a dark history tied to the Mallochrsquos Oak in the grounds of Strathallan Castle. It is said that during a famine the local miller, Malloch, hoarded flour and grain instead of distributing it to the starving locals. He was strung up from this tree as punishment.Copper beech tree, Drummond Castle Gardens, PerthshireThe formal terraced gardens include a copper beech tree planted by Queen Victoria to commemorate her visit in .The Camperdown Elm, Camperdown Park, DundeeA contorted weeping elm discovered in woods near Dundee in , it is thought to have been re-planted near what was then the Earl of Camperdownrsquos new mansion house and is now within the cityrsquos Camperdown Park.Flodden Tree, The Hirsel Estate near Coldstream, BerwickshireThis sycamore on the Hirsel Estate in the Borders is believed to have been planted in tribute to the Scottish dead at the Battle of Flodden in .Napoleonrsquos Tree, Ecclefechan, DumfriesshireDuring his final days on the Atlantic island of St Helena, Napoleon Bonaparte befriended British Army surgeon Archibald Arnott. Two days before he died, Napoleon gave instructions that no British doctor except Arnott should touch him.A weeping willow tree was Napoleonrsquos favourite spot for contemplation on the island and he asked to be buried under its shade. This wish was fulfilled when he died in  and Napoleon was interred there until being repatriated to France almost  years later.Arnott took a cutting from the tree, planting it on hishome to Ecclefechan, where it still grows in the grounds of the Kirkconnel Hall Hotel.The ldquoFilo Pastry Tree, Logan Botanic Gardens near StranraerThis impressive specimen of Polylepis australis ndash the largest of its kind in the UK ndash got its nickname from a Stranraer Academy pupil who compared the flaky bark to the filo pastry on a spring roll. Originating from South America, its peeling bark traps air to keep the tree warm at night.Redwood Avenue, Benmore Botanic Garden, ArgyllVisitors enter the gardens through the majestic Redwood Avenue which was planted in , a time when the American Civil War was at its height and Queen Victoria was on the throne. These towering Sequoiadendron giganteum are now around  metres high.Birnam Oak and Birnam Sycamore, PerthshireThe Birnam Oak and its neighbour the Birnam Sycamore are thought to be the sole surviving trees of the great forest that once straddled the banks of the River Tay. This is immortalised in Shakespearersquos Macbeth as the Birnam Wood.The ldquoBig Tree, Kirkwall, OrkneyTo be fair, the ldquoBig Tree is not actually that lofty. Rather, this -year-old sycamore is much beloved among Orcadians due to its prominent position on Kirkwallrsquos main street making it a popular meeting spot. It was voted Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year .The giants of Reelig Glen, InvernessReelig Glen boasts some of Britainrsquos tallest trees: a Douglas fir that, when measured in , came in at .fta larch measuring .fta .ft-highNorway spruce and a lime tree which stands at .ft . The Dughall Mor ndash the big dark stranger ndash a Douglas fir planted in  also grows there.Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, St Andrews UniversityA hawthorn said to have been planted by Mary, Queen of Scots in the s grows in the grounds of St Maryrsquos College at St Andrews University. Interestingly, Moray House Garden at Edinburgh University once had its own Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, believed to have been lost in the mid-th century as the teacher training college expanded.Stevensonrsquos Yew, EdinburghThe yew was a favourite play spot for Robert Louis Stevenson - author of Treasure Island, Kidnapped and the Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - as a child visiting his grandfather in the Colinton area of Edinburgh. It is said the marks of a swing are still visible on its branches.Robert Kirkrsquos Fairy Tree, AberfoyleReverend Robert Kirk wrote the book The Secret Commonwealth of Elves, Fauns And Fairies in filled with stories about those who claimed to have had contact with these mythical beings, including Kirk himself.He believed that the Doon Hill in Aberfoyle was a gateway to the world of the fairies. Kirk died in  after collapsing while visiting the hill at night. It is likely he suffered a heart attack, yet rumours swirled among local people that he been carried away by the fairies for revealing their secrets.Doon Hill is also known as ldquoFairy Knowe or ldquoDun Sithean and according to legend Kirkrsquos soul is still trapped inside a lone Scots pine. Today, people hang ribbons and messages around the trees in this area to ward off illness and bad luck or commemorate a loved one.Beech Avenue, Achnacarry, Inverness-shireThe story goes that Donald ldquoThe Gentle Lochiel Cameron heard about the arrival in Scotland of Charles Edward Stuart ndash Bonnie Prince Charlie ndash while planting this avenue of beech trees on his estate at Achnacarry, just prior to the Jacobite rising of .The inaugural Scottish Tree Festival organised by Discover Scottish Gardens features more than  tree-themed events and runs until December . title: scotlands-most-senior-trade-union-figure-faces-internal-unrest-over-outside-earnings
story: A private meeting of the Scottish Trades Union Congresslast week included a discussion on general secretary Grahame Smith, who is believed to have boosted his pay packet by around pound, for sitting on Government-linked boards.The STUCrsquos governing body is now reviewing its procedures for membership of external bodies.The Herald on Sunday contacted some of the STUCrsquos largest affiliated unions about the controversy, but many did not provide a comment.However, a spokesperson for the GMB Scotland union, which is a key part of the STUC, said: "On numerous occasions we have raised our concerns about transparency and accountability in the running of the STUC. This is to defend the jobs and conditions of the staff we represent in the STUC and to ensure the organisations future ability to campaign effectively on behalf of all its affiliate members. We will continue to address those concerns through the internal processes of the STUC."As the umbrella body for nearly  affiliated trade unions, the STUC represents around , workers and acts as the voice of organised labour north of the border.However, critics have questioned the STUCrsquos independence under Mr Smithrsquos leadership after it emerged the body received over % of its funding from the SNP Government last year.Mr Smith, who became general secretary in , has also faced sniping from within the trade union world over the way he has topped up an STUC remuneration package thought to be close to pound,.As a board member of jobs quango Scottish Enterprise between  and , Mr Smith is believed to have received up to pound, in fees.He currently has three additional posts which attract payment. As a board member of Skills Development Scotland he is entitled to between pound, and pound, a year and qualies for a pound, a year salary bump as a board member of the Scottish Qualications Authority. He can also receive a daily rate as a member of the Enterprise and Skills Enterprise Board.Mr Smith was also briefly the interim chair of the Glasgow Colleges Regional Board, for which he received pound,, but he did not not receive any remuneration for his time on the UK Commission on Employment and Skills.The payments issue was raised last week at a meeting of the STUCrsquos general council, which is comprised of union representatives.At one point, staff left the room so that affiliates could discuss matters in private, a session that lasted around two hours.It is understood unhappiness was expressed about the money Mr Smith had received since  for sitting on boards, the transparency of appointments, as well as the lack of an in-house register of interest.Others at the meeting said they were not singling out any one inidual as previous general secretaries had also sat on external boards.However, a trade union source said Mr Smith was becoming ldquomarginalised.The row also comes amid a debate within the trade union movement over male trade unionists hogging multiple posts.In a statement to this newspaper, STUC President Lynn Henderson said:ldquoThe STUC engagement with a range of public bodies is reported every year in the General Council report to our Annual Congress. The General Council is currently reviewing our processes and procedures. We are considering how these can be improved to ensure that the considerable influence the trade union movement has on such bodies and on public policy can be further enhanced.ldquoIn serving on public bodies, the General Secretary is following the same practice as his predecessors. I believe that in doing so, the General Secretary is always focused on advancing the interests of unions and working people. Grahame has served as General Secretary for  years and is widely respected throughout the trade union movement and wider civil society. During that period the STUC has continued to exert considerable influence over the direction of economic and social policy in Scotland.

title: snp-run-glasgow-council-snubs-swinney-by-removing-his-name-from-teacher-pay-letter
story: The Deputy First Minister initially co-signed the draft communication to teachers, but Glasgow city council snubbed him and put it out from their own education convener.Labour MSP Iain Gray said: "With John Swinney becoming increasingly unpopular with teachers, it is no surprise that SNP-run Glasgow City Council deleted his signature from the letter.Mr Swinney is embroiled in a bitter row with the trade unions over their demand for teachers pay to be increased by %.Council umbrella group COSLA, with the support of the Scottish Government, has offered % and strike action is on the horizon.The Government has also suggested that an overhaul of the main grade scale, coupled with the % rise, would result in some teachers getting a boost in excess of %.However, the disagreement was aggravated after the Government and COSLA agreed to go over the heads of the unions by sending a ldquojoint communication directly to teachers about the offer.The Education Secretary wanted teachers to hear his side of the pay proposal before they voted in a consultative ballot.The draft letter was co-signed by Mr Swinney and Tory councillor Gail Macgregor, who is COSLArsquos resources spokesperson, and stated:ldquoWe firmly believe that this is a fair offer which demonstrates that both Local Government and the Scottish Government value the teaching profession. We are disappointed that it has been rejected by the teacher unions.ldquoThe teacher unionsrsquo claim for % in a single year cannot be achieved. It is simply unaffordable, and the unions have been told this since their claim was submitted at the start of the year.They also said the pay offer and the grading restructuring amounted to a poundm investment in teachers.However, when teachers in Glasgow received the letter by email, the names of Mr Swinney and Ms Macgregor had vanished. The signature of SNP councillor Chris Cunningham, who is the convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, appeared instead.The wording was the same as the initial draft put together by COSLA and the Government, apart from an extra paragraph at the beginning:ldquoCOSLA Leaders agreed that a joint letter from the Scottish Government and COSLA should be prepared and sent out to teachers explaining the pay offer to them.ldquoThe information below is from the Scottish Government and COSLA which talks to the offer on the table and I would be gratefulyou could share it with teachers in your school.Glasgow was a Labour bastion at a local authority level for decades, but the SNP won control of the council for the first time last year.Around , teachers, many of whom are based in Glasgow, protested against Mr Swinney over the pay standoff at a rally in the city recently.Placards included lsquoSwinney is a ninny and lsquoEbenezer Swinneyrsquo, which an education source said was an indication of the hostility to the SNP heavyweight by teachers.A Council spokeswoman said: ldquoOur City Convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, Councillor Chris Cunningham has sent a letter to schools which includes information from the Scottish Government and Cosla on the teachers pay award proposal.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has worked with COSLA to put in place the best teacher pay deal in the UK for -.It is important that the component parts of the deal are explained in detail so that teachers have a full understanding of the proposals on the table.

title: new-series-from-sir-david-attenborough-to-start-on-bbc-one
story: Each episode of Dynasties follows a dferent animal ndashthe chimpanzee, emperor penguins, hunting dogs, lions and tigers.The naturalist has said he wason the ldquoedge of his seat watching footage from the series, which was filmed all over the world.He said: ldquoDynasties came from an idea that it would be interesting to follow a particular group of animals which scientists watching them had thought was going to have some kind of revolution.ldquoMaybe lions taking over a dferent pride, maybe chimpanzees having a competition for leadership.ldquoThen the producer made a very bold statement: we will put a crew, a film crew, and we will film exactly what happened, and we donrsquot know whether itrsquoll be a triumph, we donrsquot know whether itrsquoll be a tragedy. But wersquoll show you the truth.ldquoI only saw it when the films were finally edited and came back. And they didnrsquot tell me what was going to happen and I was on the edge of my seat too because in the most remarkable way you identy with some of these characters.A story of power, politics and the fight for survival. Wersquove been waiting a whole year to hear Sir David Attenboroughrsquos narration again. Yoursquoll want sound on! # #Dynastiespic NqrTPdmdash BBC OneNovember , Describing the first episode of the series, he said: ldquoTherersquos an aged old chimpanzee, which we used the names which the scientists themselves used who are watching it, and they called this chimpanzee, I must say a bit to my embarrassment, they called it David.ldquoAnyway he was this rather alarming alpha male who threw his weight around a bit but was obviously coming to the end of his rule, and I didnrsquot know what was going to happen, they hadnrsquot told me.ldquoAnd I watched the finished film with my eyes wide open because it was an amazing and very involving drama.ldquoAnd thatrsquos the benefit of following these animals in this kind of way, that you become very, very involved.Another episode in the series follows a group of emperor penguins in the Antarctic, and Sir David said: ldquoThe emperor penguin programme is slightly dferent from all the rest because itrsquos not about one particular emperor penguin or family, and indeed you couldnrsquot tell because all emperor penguins look exactly the same.ldquoThe only way they can survive in the heart of the Antarctic isthe males endure the winter with their eggs sitting on their feet, throughout the hideous blizzards they sit there in a huddle and the blizzard comes in.ldquoAnd after a bit the chap, the males in the front they canrsquot survive any longer unless they blow this for a game of marbles and they walk around the side and they come round the back.ldquoBut this is filmed in such detail and with such skill and in such circumstances that well, you may think yoursquove seen emperor penguins, but until yoursquove seen this programme you really havenrsquot.Sir David has also said the series highlights the problem of how to allow animals enough space as the human population encroaches on their habitats.He said: ldquoAnimals also deserve a space on this planet. We are latecomers and the animals were there before us. And maybe we should be taking care of them, making allowance for them, giving them space.Dynasties begins on BBC One at .pm.

title: armistice-centenary-silences-observed-in-australia-and-new-zealand
story: Tens of thousands of Australians and New Zealanders gave their lives in the First World War.Thousands gathered for a national service of remembrance at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra, where Prime Minister Scott Morrison led a minutersquos silence at am .In Sydney, crowds gathered at the Anzac Memorial, an extension of which was unveiled by the Duke of Sussex during his recent trip with Meghan, while there was also a service at the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.The Commemorative Address is being delivered by The Honourable Scott Morrison, Prime Minister of Australia. #HonourTheirSpirit #RemembranceDay pic XWVOlsmevLmdash Aust War MemorialNovember , Some , Australians served overseas during the First World War, the vast majority of whom fought on the Western Front alongside British soldiers and their allies.Over , died in the conflict, more than two-thirds on the battlefields of Europe.Over three thousand people joined in remembrance and hope at the #Armistice National Ceremony at #Pukeahu in #Wellington, marking the centenary of the th hour of the th day of the th month, , when war gave way to peace https:t.co niDbsbLs pic FFdxZNZmdash WW New ZealandNovember , Earlier, large crowds attended the Pukeahu National War Memorial Park in Wellington for New Zealandrsquos main remembrance ceremony, where a minutersquos silence was observed at am .Nearly , served in New Zealand units overseas, with around a fth never ing home.

title: theresa-may-faces-struggle-to-keep-brexit-plans-on-track-amid-tory-tensions
story: With the shock resignation of pro-Europe transport minister Jo Johnson continuing to cause ructions in Tory ranks, the Prime Minister is running out of time to seal an EU exit deal.Hope of getting the Cabinet to sign off on Brexit deal proposals this week appeared to be rapidly receding as it was reported the EU had rejected UK plans for an independent arbitration clause that could allow the UK to quit a backstop deal on the Northern Ireland border.With both pro and anti-withdrawal Tories becoming more vocal in their opposition to Mrs Mayrsquos stance, arch-Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg called on the PM to change tack.He urged Mrs May to end the deadlock by paying the EU pound billion to secure a ldquono deal plus arrangement with the bloc after withdrawal.Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Mr Rees-Mogg, who heads the influential European Research Group of  Tory MPs, suggested offering the financial deal to Brussels in order toldquomake our departure as amicable as possible.Previously critical of the pound billion orce bill the UK is set to pay the EU, Mr Rees-Mogg wrote: ldquoIt is time for convinced Brexiteers like me to compromise.ldquoSo, at this late hour in the negotiations, we would like to make a new, generous offer to break the deadlock, to achieve a lsquoNo Deal Plusrsquo.ldquoIt would cost us money but it would finally dispel the lsquocrash outrsquo Project Fear nightmare scenarios.A Government source told the Press Association: ldquoThe end part of negotiations were always going to be tough.ldquoThere are a number of issues that need to be worked through on the Northern Ireland backstop and these are the most dficult.ldquoThey include ensuring that,it is ever needed, it is not permanent and there is a mechanism to ensure the UK could not be held in the arrangement indefinitely.Well done to @JoJohnsonUK on standing up for what he believes in. He was a fantastic Minister to work with whilst we were at the DfE. Itrsquos a sad loss for Gvt, but Brexit is above party politics. https:t.co icoTQDFvmdash Justine GreeningNovember , Former Cabinet minister Justine Greening, who shares Mr Johnsonrsquos view that a fresh referendum is needed, called on Tories to oppose the PMrsquos Chequers proposals.She told The Observer: ldquoThe parliamentary deadlock has been clear for some time. Itrsquos crucial now for Parliament to vote down this plan, because it is the biggest giveaway of sovereignty in modern times.The view was echoed by Brexiteer Tory MP Andrew Bridgen who told a meeting of the Bruges Group: ldquoIf we canrsquot chuck Chequers then itrsquos time to chuck the Prime Minister.Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker and DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson wrote in The Sunday : ldquoIf the Government makes the historic mistake of prioritising placating the EU over establishing an independent and whole UK, then, regrettably, we must vote against the deal.Brexiteers have insisted that the UK should not get involved with a potentially permanent backstop customs union agreement with the EU as the price of avoiding a hard border in Northern Ireland.

title: silhouettes-of-tommies-projected-on-to-famous-uk-landmarks
story: The Tommies illuminated Marble Arch, Tate Modern, HMS Belfast, Warwick Castle, the Angel of the North, the Tyne Bridge, Titanic Belfast, Cardf Castle and Edinburgh Castle.The silhouettes have appeared all over the UK since the campaign launched in February, commemorating the British and Commonwealth troops who died in the First World War whilst also raising funds for military charities.General the Lord Dannatt, patron of There But Not There and former chief of the general staff, said: ldquoAs we reach  years since the Armistice, it is vital that we reflect on the sacrice made by an entire generation of servicemen and women.ldquoThese wonderful landmarks coming together provide a remarkable representation of the nation doing exactly just that.ldquoWe have been incredibly moved by the overwhelming public support that we have received across the country, which has led to more than pound million raised for military and mental health charities.ldquoHowever, our journey doesnrsquot stop here we need the publicrsquos backing more than ever in raising funds to support our veterans in crisis.ldquoMental health remains a crucial issue and we hope people will see these poignant silhouettes and be inspired to buy their own Tommy to both remember the fallen and to help those that continue to struggle today.

title: number-of-workers-earning-less-than-living-wage-increasing-study-claims
story: Analysis of the Scottish labour market indicates that, people are now earning less than the living wage of pound. per hour.It represents an increase of , on the , people cited in the report for .The hourly living wage rate for adults in  was set at pound..The study suggests that the health and education sectors have seen the largest increase in the number of people earning less than the living wage.In health and social work services, employees were earning less than the living wage in  ndash an increase of% on the  people in .In education,  people were recorded as earning under the living wage ndash the numberincreased by % to  people in .In the accommodation and food services sector, were earning less than the living wage in . The SNP should hang its head in shame.ldquoThose in the health and education sectors perform valuable work ndash they deserve much better than poverty pay.ldquoUnder Labour work will pay, with a pound per hour real living wage, a ban on zero-hours contracts and better rights with more security at work.ldquoUnder the broken economy of the SNP and the Tories, more and more people are on poverty pay in Scotland this year, than last ndash including some of the most valued workers in society.ldquoLabour governments at Holyrood and Westminster have a plan to end poverty pay, including introducing a real living wage of pound an hour and an industrial strategy that will deliver high-wage, high-skill jobs across Scotland.Business Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoDespite the UK Governmentrsquos austerity agenda, Scotland has the highest proportion of employees being paid at least the real Living Wage of all four UK nations.
